section.title: Motivation
section.para: Gwyddion is a modular programme for SPM data analysis. Primarily it is supposed to be used for analysis of height fields obtained by means of scanning probe microscopy techniques (AFM, MFM, STM, NSOM), but generally it can be used for any other height field analysis or image analysis. Gwyddion is a free software, covered by Gnu General Public License (Gnu GPL).

The main idea behind Gwyddion developement is to provide modular programme for 2D data analysis that could be easily extended by modules and plugins with no need of core recompilation. Moreover, the status of free software enables to provide source codes to developers and users, which makes the further programme improvement easier.

Gwyddion can be currently used with Linux and Windows(TM) operating systems. Both families of systems can be used also for developement. For graphical interface, Gtk+ (www.gtk.org) libraries are used, therefore it can be bacically ported on any system that is supported by Gtk+.

Gwyddion core developement is currently funded by Czech Metrology Institute (www.cmi.cz). The project started as a part of the Nanomet initiative in August, 2003. It is supposed that more persons and institutions will participate on developement. Project is open for anyone. Welcome...

section.title: Licensing
section.para:
Gwyddion is covered by Gnu General Public License (Gnu GPL). See appendix for full License text. In particular, this means that:
you can freely make copies and modify them. You can download the programme and its source code from the Gwyddion pages and modify it as you want - however, the modified code will be still covered by the same license.
if you add any part to the programme (e. g. if you write a module), your code must be also covered by Gnu GPL. The only exception are plugins that are run as a separate programmes communicating with Gwyddion. Plugins therefore can have any license.
The main reasons, why the programme is covered by this kind of license: first of all, this licensing policy enables us to make modular programme that can be easily developed my many persons from different institutions. Second, this license protects the rights of developers that their code, here given to public, cannot be copied and used for commercial purposes.

chapter.title: Installing Gwyddion
chapter.para:
Gwyddion source code and binaries can be downloaded from the web pages of the project (http://gwyddion.net). The instalation sligtly varies depending on the operating system used. However, basically it consist of two steps:
Installing the Gtk+ enviroment (if not allready done).
Installing Gwyddion
The first step is necessary namely on operating systems other than Linux at first Gwyddion installation. The version of Gtk+ enviroment necessary for your system is desribed in the next sections. Generally, you need a Gtk+ development package for Gwyddion developement and Gtk+ libraries (runtime package) for running Gwyddion.
We recommend you to download example Gwyddion files too. These are in native Gwyddion format and represent typical AFM data.

section.title: Linux version
section.para:
You can use RPMs or source tarballs as Gwyddion installation source. Then, install the RPM or compile and install programme in a usual way. Depending on source you should do following:
Using RPM: run rpm -Uhv gwyddion-X.Y.rpm (where gwyddion-X.Y.rpm is the gwyddion installation RPM you have downloaded.)
Using source tarball. Unpack the tarball and run autogen.sh; make; make install for generating Makefiles dependent on your architecture, compiling and installing the application.

section.title: Windows version
section.para: Download the Gtk+ runtime enviroment and install it (e. g. from http://www.dropline.net/gtk/download.php). Download Gwyddion installator and install Gwyddion. You should need no more steps for Gwyddion runtime installation.

section.title: Linux version for developers
section.para: The installation for developers on Linux is same as the usual installation from source tarball.

section.title: Windows version for developers
section.para:
If you want to become developer, you can use Microsoft Visual C++ compiler to compile the application. Use source tarball in that case and compile application using Nmake command. In this case you will need Gtk development enviromet installed on your system. You can download this enviroment from http://www.dropline.net/gtk/download.php. You will probably need to change paths to Gtk+ and MSVC toplevel directories in the make.msc file. The default paths are (see first few lines of make.msc):
# XXX: set following to your Gtk+-Development and MSVC paths GTK_TOP = C:\Dev-C++ MSC_TOP = C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\VC98

section.title: Main window
section.para: The main window is the only Gwyddion part that appears after start with no parameters. It consist of set of Gwyddion menus: File, Edit, Data Process, Graph and Externs, and from several rows of buttons connected with tools and modules (accesible also by menus).
File menu associates commands that are used for file input and output. Global commands (e. g. Exit) are located here too. Submenu command names are self-explanatory (Load, Save, etc.).

Edit menu constist of commands that are applicable on more data windows (e. g. Data arithmetic) and commands that change status of data window presentation or selection. Masks and presentations options can be also set here.

Data process menu is build automatically from all the modules available at the Gwyddion modules durectory (depending on operating system). Modules are responsible for all the data processing, so this menu item associates most of the commands you will need at analyzing your SPM data.
Graph menu consist of commands that are applicable on graphs. Graph processing includes reading values of graphs, measuring profile distances etc.
Externs are commands that provide information about height field metadata (e. g. scanning speed, tip voltage, etc.) and information about the Gwyddion (About).

section.title: Managing files
section.para: Gwyddion uses its internal data format (.gwy) to store data. The main advantage of this format is fact, that it stores complete state of processing of concrete data, including selections and other tool and processing fucntion settings. Therefore we recommned to use this format for saving processed files.

Other data file formats can be handled with appropriate loading and saving modules or plugins. Currently, only simple file formats can be used with Gwyddion. This means namely graphical file types (JPEG, PNG, PPM, TIFF, BMP) and raw binary and ASCII data. With io_tm plugin (distributed separately) you can load data from ThermoMicroscopes (Veeco) SpmLab #R4 and #R5 version binary files.
We expect that much more file IO modules and plugins will be written soon, depending on demands and file format specifications available.

section.title: Data windows
section.para: Data window is used for 2D data presentation to user. It is the main widget used for working with Gwyddion. The data are presented to user as a field of false colors correponding to heights. Color axis that represents mapping the colors to real height values is also part of the data window.

Graph window is used for 1D data processing. You can get it only by using appropriate tools or modules that extract some graphs from height field data. Currently, it is not possible to load graphs into application as the main intent of Gwyddion is to provide tools for analyzing height fields, not graphs.

section.title: Modules and tools
section.para: Modules are responsible for most of the Gwyddion features.
Tools are a special kind of modules that can work with selections.

section.title: Presentations and masks
section.para: Presentations can be used to show the height field in other way than as false colors map of heights. Currently, only one presentation method - shading - is implemented.
Masks are used for displaying special areal selections (e. g. grains).

section.title: Plugins
section.para: Plugins are separate programmes that can communicate with gwyddion. From the point of user, the way of using plugins is same as for modules. From the point of developer, plugins are programmes that can load or save Gwyddion DUMB file format. They do not use any of Gwyddion libraries and therefore they are independent on Gwyddion licensing.

chapter.title: Developing Gwyddion
chapter.para: You are encouraged to become a developer of Gwyddion.

section.title: API References
section.para: There are many functions that can help you while developing your module. Please, see API reference.

section.title: Bug reports
section.para: We will be very happy if you send as bug reports if you find errors in Gwyddion. For doing this, please, specify as much as possible the situation which leaded to error, operating system and Gwyddion version used. You can also send us the SPM data that were processed when problem was found, this is necessary namely for reporting bugs in file loading/saving modules and plugins.
